segments.text: I mean, that's one of the problems with the Hanoi.
Okay.
Why do we use a one-year tour instead of a duration tour?
Well, this was what they decided to do, and I don't think we would use duration ever, really.
I mean, we didn't use it in the Second World War.
But that one year, I think, was a mistake.
because it's hard to build up the morale of units and get used to them.
But I think two years would have been better, or eighteen months.
We've had quite a few men who've said, because it wasn't even units that win, it was individuals— That's correct.
—and that you get to battle and you really want to know if that guy behind you is going to stay there or turn around and run.
That's right.
Well, that's a debatable issue.
They did it because they wanted people to know that
They'd much rather have a great many Americans go over there and do their year than to hang the burden of this on a limited number of people.
And they were worried initially also about how Americans from a temperate climate would operate in a tropical climate and so on, because parts of it were tropical.
So there were a number of considerations, and, you know, it's a perfectly good issue
asked several times that they be mobilized.
I don't know.
See, I didn't remember in 1965.
I came in in 1966, and a lot of the decisions were made in 1965 before my time.
I don't know.
You're talking about the—you mean the— National Reserve.
You mean the National Guard?
Yes, sir.
Well, I don't know.
We had conscription, and the—I don't know.
I mean, a lot of people in the National Guard were conscripted, but I don't know the answer to that question.
Okay.
Thank you.
The U.S. did not want to create an image of a colonial empire fighting in Asia, and what impact did this have on
decision-making as far as maybe troop strength and maybe even the role of the military as far as maybe the general having one—Harvin in the U.S. under one command, under one leader?
Well, Westy had command of everything but effective command, even over
most of the naval forces that were close in.
One thing he didn't have were the B-36s, but he had a lot of B-52s, rather, but he had a lot of influence over the targets on the B-52s.
I don't think the question of unity of command was terribly important in the fight.
And I don't think the question of not appearing in a colonial empire or anything like that.
We were fighting for the independence of this country as we were in Korea, and we had more non-U.S. forces there.
We had two Australians, New Zealanders, two Korean
Philippines.
That was mainly cosmetic.
But the—I don't know.
We weren't—that was for the newspapers back home and the student protesters, not for the people of Asia.
They knew what we were doing.
How much did LBJ's belief that the U.S. was the policeman of the world make his commitment to Vietnam even stronger?
really are a silly young man.
Who, what is your evidence that he believed the United States was the policeman of the world?
Well, to tell you the truth, I read it out of John Stessinger's book here, Crusaders and Pragmatists, and that's what he considers LBJ, that possibly us going into Guatemala in 1965.
He didn't go to Guatemala in 1965.
Or the Dominican Republic.
the Latin Americans wouldn't acknowledge it, but then he had an OAS operation there, a very successful OAS election, and he was in there for serious strategic reasons under OAS doctrine.
But the point about it is, if you've ever worked with a president, you know, the last thing in the world he wants to do is commit U.S. forces.
The last thing.
And the notion that, I don't care who, I don't know who Sessinger is, but

The point is that the notion—and there are any number of cases in the six, eight years I was there in which, you know, we just let something happen rather than get involved, whether it was Westerion or Ghana or, you know, Guinea or Guantanamo, where you just turned off the water, you know, and they turned off the water, so we went and got another alternative source of water.
president the last thing in the world, because aside from the human fact that people get killed when you start fighting, and you're commander-in-chief, and don't think that's trivial.
You lose all sense of it in these books you read.
But the other thing a politician knows, he's going to lose in the polls by getting involved, unless it's some very, you know, quick, cosmetic thing like Grenada.
But the
they know what happened at Truman and what happens in any protracted war on democracy.
So Lyndon Johnson had, you know, burning cities, a tremendous program he wanted to get through.
He inherited the race crisis, which from Watson on was roaring through the northern cities, a really very dangerous phase.
wanted to do a lot about social welfare, and he did.
And he had this war he inherited.
The notion that he was out looking to be a policeman of the world was just nonsense.
My last question would be, did Nixon overcome the Tocqueville Oscillation, or did he give in to it?
Well, it's a good question.
It's the first good question you've asked.
I think that he was, there was a certain amount of it that he felt he had to give in to.
You know, the Guam Doctrine were pulling back, and I remember at that time a Soviet didn't sit.
Well, our policy will be to move into the empty chairs left by U.S. diplomacy.
And there was that 69 thing, which
doctrine of extending power around the whole periphery of Asia, from Vladivostok through the Indian Ocean to Ethiopia, which was enunciated by Brezhnev about that.
But basically, I think if he hadn't collapsed with Watergate, you might have had a fairly stable period.
I don't think for a minute they would have gone in in 75.
And, uh, but once
the system, the president lost legitimacy.
And that took place in the course of the year 73, I'd say, before he actually was president.
You could just see it dragging him down and limiting him, and then the Congress getting like a voracious animal.
What is it?
And the domestic economy really is struggling, too.
And the domestic economy is struggling.
Well, that's why this thing is so interesting.
Communists do something which they call correlation of force analysis.
If you want to see what it is, get this fellow's account and see what he takes into account here.
And it's fascinating, because it really is
He says, well, we took stock.
We took stock.
And here's what they said, all right.
Morale was shot and was greatly weakened with the enemy's forces.
Fiscal, 72, 73—this was fiscal years.
The U.S. had given the puppet troops 2.2 billion.
This aid was reduced to 900 million, 73, 74, 700 million.
Thieu was then forced to fight a poor man's war.
Mobility was reduced by a half.
Then here comes Watergate scandals, resignation, Nixon, economic recession, mounting inflation, serious unemployment, and an oil crisis.
And those things lined all up together.
cut to his throat, and they're tied up with all this stuff, and that's why they did it.

I don't think they would have done it if Nixon—after all, he had the biggest victory, practically, as big a victory as any president had in 72, which is not—it was partly peace and prosperity, but it was partly running against McGovern, a very weak candidate.
And he had a clear run, and he blew it.
And this whole system went out of whack.
And, of course, you did have these problems, the other problems, but it was mainly a situation in which the president self-destructed, and the system doesn't work without a president.
So I think that it's—he had a fair chance.
In fact, I did a paper the other day, delivered it in Ohio, on how the Cold War might end.
It's really on the Tocqueville Oscillation.
I said in retrospect, I think this third cycle we've had was unnecessary, and—but I won't burden you with that.
The short answer is to your question.
I think Nixon had a chance, but water gave blue.
Okay.
And then something semi—a lot of people now are starting to—the Vietnam Syndrome, I believe you know, we were in.
pretty much with Carter, that we don't want to get involved.
We're sort of almost isolationist.
And in Central America now, a lot of people are making comparisons between Vietnam and Central America and saying, you know, we're going down the same road.
So are we currently then with Central America involved in the oscillation, in your opinion?
Do you think we could maybe do more than we're doing?
I don't know enough about Central America.
I've written, well, a dozen or so books since leaving government, and this was the second of them.
And I really haven't worked on it.
So I don't know about Central America.
Off the hip, maybe?
What is it?
Off the hip, just shooting away what you think just off the top of your head?
No, I'm not going to shoot off— There we go.
Well, can I turn off the tape recorder and then maybe— No, I don't really know.
Before you can form a serious judgment, you've got to know, I don't know what the internal situation is in Nicaragua.
I've got an impression I don't know what the Russians feel, whether the Russians want to push this hard or Castro wants to push it hard.
I don't have any—there's too many questions I can't answer, so let's leave it.
My last question here— This is the third last question.
This is my last one.
This is your last one.
This is.
I guarantee it.
You stated that Johnson said that in this job you must set a standard for making decisions.
That's right.
Mine is, what will my grandchildren think of my administration when I'm buried under the tree at the ranch?
Correct.
What do you think they will think of his policy in Vietnam now, twenty years after we got initially involved?
I tell you, I don't think it's—
I don't think we will know.
I'll tell you why.
Are you still trying to figure it out?
No, I'll tell you something else.
I think that the importance he attached to Southeast Asia and Asia will be recognized as correct.
the notion that, as one of my old friends and colleagues said at the time, let's return Southeast Asia to the obscurity it so richly deserves.
I don't think that's it.
That is going to be the view of history.
I think it's an extremely important strategic part of the world.
And out of the accident of the way it happened in 75, the worst didn't happen.
It's really the next to the worst happened.
If the President of the United States had said, this is all a mistake, I'm pulling out, and Congress backed him, then you would have had a true catastrophe.
But Congress did it.
The President stood out.
Maya Ghez was a symbol of that, and Ford.
And then Ford, and then Jimmy Carter, and now Reagan have thrown their weight of support behind ASEAN.
you're left with a very dangerous position for Thailand and the Russians in Cam Ranh Bay and the Russians at the Vang airfield.
But still, Southeast Asia has not collapsed.
Indochina has collapsed.
And what we're trying to prevent is what we have now, which is communist forces on this long and very difficult frontier of Thailand.
Now, if out of the dynamics of history
Finally, they never get around to trying to take over Thailand.
If they do, there's going to be a war.
Let's take the best.
There's no way they have to take over Thailand.
Finally, a generation comes along in Hanoi and says, We can't go on at seventy-five dollars per income.
Everyone around here has got two thousand dollars.
We've got to develop like the rest of Asia.
And they get bored with being
colonial power in Cambodia and Laos, go home and start raising some, you know, industry.
They'd be very good at it if they could only get some leaders who were interested in it.
And they become part of Asia, this vital Asia, and the whole thing subsides.
Then what'll it be?
It'll be what Lyndon Johnson did.
And the people of Asia was by ten critical years
I think everyone would agree, and if you look back, the thing would have collapsed in 55 if the United States had said, sorry, boys, you're nice fellows, but this is not our interest.
We signed that thing in 55, but we don't really believe it's in 65.
But it was different ten years later.
So there's a fair chance, but I don't know.
that people will say, well, it was not what they should have done, and if they went into it, they should have won.

But in any case, an independent Southeast Asia is the result, which is stabilizing for everybody—India, China—is a result of the very painful ten years that America took and the South—people in the area took.
It's not what—the way he meant it to happen, but the ten years had that result.
Otherwise, of course, Lyndon Johnson is a major figure in the history of Asia.
And that's what I had to go and talk at Hofstra in Vietnam, and I didn't particularly want to.
I picked one point that's missed in all these history books.
I said, I'm not going to debate all these old things again.
But something you perhaps don't know, which is not only Lyndon Johnson's view of Asia,
and Howe's position on Vietnam related to that.
But Howe's decision related to his civil rights position.
And he—it all ties into the convergence of his struggle for the 1957 Civil Rights Act and statehood for Hawaii.
But I went into that little story.
And he really had a sense
how important the issue was going to be, and he didn't require a computer to calculate it, even an abacus, he could see.
And he talked, I don't know, he looked at this passage in his East-West Center speech when he started out in 66.
But if there's a chance that it'll come out tolerably well, in that very limited sense I've just expressed
But it may not, and he may not.

And if it does, then another war has to be fought over the independence, because no one is going to let Southeast Asia be taken over by a major power, not China or Russia or India or U.S. And so if there's a real plunge for Thailand,
I don't think the Russians know that.
And the Russians have got a lot of problems, so it may not happen.
Thank you very much.
